page.title: 04NATURE AND CHURCHILL
page.content: Almost all the arable land around the village is now devoted to winter wheat (the result of EEC agricultural policy). This monoculture, with the associated intensive spraying and hedge removal, severely reduces the number of plant, insect and animal species in the fields. On the positive side however, the road verges, left uncut because of economies by the District Council, show an increasing variety of flowering plants, and along with this an increase in the range of insect life. Just now (August) the verges are colourful with scabious, knapweed, bellflower, yarrow, tansy and toadflax. There are several public footpaths and bridleways around Churchill, and these, particularly the latter, are regularly used.
